population_specificity: 57 patients with chronic heart failure (New York Heart Association class II and III).
effective_dosage: 15 minutes of walking at 50% reserved heart rate.
study_duration: The intervention duration is not explicitly stated in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a wearable rehabilitation robot (curara®) on gait training in stroke patients compared to conventional therapist-assisted gait training.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in main outcomes (10mWT and 6MWD) between the two groups, but intragroup improvements in gait speed, stride length, stride duration, and cadence were observed. Stride duration and cadence improved more significantly in the robot-assisted group.
population_specificity: Stroke patients (n=35 analyzed).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of gait training (5 times per week), each lasting 30±5 minutes per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a group-based intervention for increasing physical activity, including walking, among insufficiently active African American women.
results_summary: The study compared a 10-week group-based intervention with a standard physical activity program, measuring outcomes like total physical activity minutes, walking speed, and other secondary metrics. Results are expected to show greater improvements in the intervention group, with social affiliation variables evaluated as mediators.
population_specificity: Insufficiently active African American women (n=360).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved shared goal-setting via Fitbits and group activities).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to document a rare case of anti-GQ1b antibody syndrome presenting with vomiting as the initial symptom followed by abnormal gait, to expand clinical awareness of the condition.
results_summary: The study reported a child with anti-GQ1b antibody syndrome who initially presented with vomiting and later developed abnormal gait, which resolved after treatment with IVIG and glucocorticoids, enabling normal walking at follow-up.
population_specificity: A single pediatric case (child) with anti-GQ1b antibody syndrome.
study_duration: Treatment duration not specified; follow-up was 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of moderate-intensity walking on postprandial blood glucose control in pregnant individuals with and without gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: The study found that the GDM group had higher fasting, 24-h mean, and daily peak glucose values compared to the NON-GDM group across all conditions. Participants completed different walking protocols (short vs. long duration) and indicated their preference via a physical activity enjoyment scale (PACES).
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals with (GDM) and without gestational diabetes mellitus (NON-GDM).
effective_dosage: Three 10-minute walks immediately after eating (SHORT) or one 30-minute walk outside of 1 hour after eating (LONG).
study_duration: 5 days of exercise protocols, preceded and separated by 2 days of habitual exercise (total 14-day monitoring period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a combined training program (CTP) in reducing the effects of dual tasking on gait parameters in individuals with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The CTP reduced the negative effects of dual tasking on stride length and velocity of the center of mass after 24 weeks of training, but had no effect on the cost of the double task after 12 weeks. Dual tasking significantly increased double-support time but had minimal impact on single-support time.
population_specificity: 22 subjects diagnosed with multiple sclerosis (Expanded Disability Status Scale score 0-5.5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of electrical stimulation (ES) on gross motor function, walking speed, step length, and daily living activities in children with cerebral palsy (CP).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that ES significantly improved gross motor function, walking speed, step length, and daily living activities in children with CP, but showed no significant effect on muscle strength.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy (265 in the test group, 263 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test associations between early mobilisation (including walking) and subacute blood pressure (BP) and survival in intracerebral haemorrhage (ICH) patients.
results_summary: Early mobilisation within 24 hours was not associated with increased odds of death by 30 days and was linked to lower mean systolic BP and lower diastolic BP variability over 72 hours.
population_specificity: 1372 consecutive spontaneous ICH patients admitted between 2013 and 2018.
study_duration: Mobilisation assessed within 24 hours of onset; BP monitored for 72 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a machine learning-based mortality risk signature for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) patients, using clinical parameters including six-minute walking distance.
results_summary: The study identified six-minute walking distance as one of seven key parameters in a highly predictive mortality risk signature for PAH, with poor walking performance associated with high-risk clusters.
population_specificity: 183 PAH patients from three Austrian expert centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding alirocumab to statin therapy affects SFA atherosclerosis, downstream flow, and walking performance in PAD patients.
results_summary: The study found that alirocumab did not significantly alter SFA plaque volume, calf perfusion, or 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) despite significant LDL lowering.
population_specificity: 35 patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) on maximally tolerated statin therapy (64 ± 8 years, 57% women, 49% Black individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety, feasibility, and functional effectiveness of HAL® locomotion training in the initial rehabilitation of acute spinal cord injury (SCI) patients.
results_summary: Significant improvements were observed in HAL®-associated parameters (walking time, distance, speed) and functional outcomes (10 MWT, 6 MWT, TUG-test). WISCI-II-Score and LEMS also increased significantly compared to pre-training status.
population_specificity: Fifty acute SCI patients (14 women, 36 men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of walking capacity (measured via the six-minute walk test) on postoperative health-related quality of life (HRQOL) in Japanese colorectal cancer patients.
results_summary: Walking capacity (6MWT) was strongly correlated with improved physical functioning and general health perception post-surgery. The study identified cutoff values (552.5 meters for physical functioning and 480.3 meters for general health perception) for clinically relevant HRQOL improvement.
population_specificity: 106 Japanese colorectal cancer patients (69 men; mean age 62.6 ± 12.4 years).
study_duration: Assessed at baseline (pre-surgery) and four weeks post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the time to first edge-of-bed mobilization in critically ill adults with severe versus non-severe COVID-19 pneumonia and describe early rehabilitation interventions, including walking.
results_summary: The study found that early rehabilitation, including walking, could be maintained within 72 hours regardless of disease severity, with a median time-to-edge-of-bed mobilization of fewer than 4 days. Disease severity and advanced organ support significantly delayed mobilization.
population_specificity: Critically ill adults with COVID-19 pneumonia requiring ICU admission for ≥72 hours, divided into severe (PaO2/FiO2 ≤100 mmHg) and non-severe (PaO2/FiO2 >100 mmHg) subgroups.
study_duration: Median time-to-edge-of-bed mobilization was 3.9 days overall (2.5 days for non-severe, 7.2 days for severe).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of robotic-assisted gait training (RAGT) on 3D gait parameters and muscle activation in subacute stroke patients and evaluate its clinical effect on walking function.
results_summary: After 4 weeks of RAGT, the experimental group showed significant improvements in walking speed, temporal symmetry, stride length, joint range of motion, and clinical scales (FMA-LE, FAC, 6MWT), indicating optimized gait and muscle activation patterns compared to conventional training.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients with hemiplegia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether perturbation-based balance training (PBT) compared to regular treadmill walking reduced daily-life fall rates among community-dwelling older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in daily-life fall rates with PBT, though laboratory fall rates decreased significantly. Other fall-related metrics in daily life were unaffected.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 65+ who could walk without aids (mean age 72, 56% female).
effective_dosage: Four 20-minute sessions (three in the first week, one after 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of robot-assisted gait training compared to conventional overground gait training on clinical outcomes in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Robot-assisted gait training showed significant short-term improvements in walking velocity, endurance, mobility, balance, and fatigue, particularly with grounded exoskeletons, but no significant differences were observed at follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term treatment durability of the GORE VIABAHN VBX Balloon Expandable Endoprosthesis for aortoiliac lesions, including its impact on walking impairment status.
results_summary: The study found sustained improvements in walking impairment status, with the majority of subjects remaining asymptomatic (Rutherford category 0) at 3 and 5 years. Quality of life measures also showed long-term improvement.
population_specificity: Subjects with de novo or restenotic aortoiliac lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of physical activity interventions, including walking, on sleep across different populations with sleep disturbances.
results_summary: The study found that all types of physical activity, including walking, were effective for improving sleep in all populations studied, with self-tolerated PA being safe for improving sleep in the elderly and comorbid or perinatal populations.
population_specificity: Healthy working-age adults, healthy older adults, perinatal women, patients with cancer, mental illness-related subjects, and other disease-related populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cueing modalities (visual, auditory) could reduce Freezing of Gait (FOG) and improve FOG-related gait parameters in Parkinson's disease (PD) patients, and whether medication state (ON-OFF) affects cueing effectiveness.
results_summary: The study found that visual and auditory cues improved preparatory phases of gait initiation, spatio-temporal parameters during walking, and reduced turning time and step time variability. Some benefits of cueing on FOG and gait-related parameters were identified, but questions remain about optimal behavioral strategies for different FOG features and PD characteristics.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients experiencing Freezing of Gait (FOG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of a web-based, pedometer-mediated walking intervention to increase physical activity in COPD patients who declined or had not participated in pulmonary rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention, which included step monitoring, feedback, individualized goals, and motivational content, aimed to improve daily step counts and secondary outcomes like exercise capacity and quality of life. Results for CAPRI-1 (12-week intervention) and CAPRI-2 (maintenance post-PR) were pending at the time of the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who declined pulmonary rehabilitation or met referral guidelines but had not participated.
study_duration: 12 weeks for CAPRI-1; 12 months follow-up for CAPRI-2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pooled effects of fampridine on gait status in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) by evaluating walking test results before and after treatment.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 18 studies showed that fampridine improved gait imbalance in MS patients, with a pooled standardized mean difference (SMD) of -1.97 for the MS Walking Scale (MSWS-12). Most studies were not placebo-controlled, but results indicated significant improvement post-treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (mean age 44-56 years, EDSS scores 4-6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Non-Pharmaceutical Chinese Medical (NPCM) therapies, including acupuncture, for treating Degenerative Lumbar Spinal Stenosis (DLSS), particularly focusing on pain relief, lumbar function, and walking capacity.
results_summary: The study found that acupuncture was significantly superior to sham acupuncture in improving intermediate-term back pain, lumbar function, disability, and walking capacity, with modest effects on short-term outcomes. Evidence for other NPCM therapies was inconclusive due to insufficient quality.
population_specificity: Patients with Degenerative Lumbar Spinal Stenosis (DLSS) (2965 participants across 37 studies).
study_duration: 6-8 weeks for acupuncture, with follow-up at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the efficacy of acupuncture therapy (AT) in improving lung function, quality of life, and exercise capacity in patients with stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that AT significantly improved lung function (FVC, FEV1, FEV1%, FEV1/FVC), quality of life (SGRQ), and exercise capacity (6MWD) in stable COPD patients, with a higher effective rate compared to the control group. Subgroup analyses confirmed these benefits across different comparison models and treatment durations.
population_specificity: Stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients (2130 participants across 28 RCTs).
study_duration: Varied (subgroup analysis included treatments ≥8 weeks and <8 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Hand-Arm Bimanual Intensive Therapy Including Lower Extremities (HABIT-ILE) for improving motor function, walking endurance, and daily living activities in adults with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The study compared 50 hours of HABIT-ILE against usual motor activity and rehabilitation, assessing outcomes at baseline, 3 weeks, and 3 months. Primary and secondary outcomes included improvements in hand strength, dexterity, bimanual motor control, walking endurance, and participation in daily activities.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥40 years with chronic stroke and acquired hemiparesis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an 8-week aerobic walking program in improving female sexual dysfunction (SD) in patients with systemic autoimmune rheumatic disorders (SARDs).
results_summary: The study found that an 8-week aerobic walking program was successful in improving female SD, though the majority of included studies were of low methodological quality.
population_specificity: Females with systemic autoimmune rheumatic disorders (SARDs), including systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of non-drainage versus drainage procedures on proprioceptive and functional recovery, as well as postoperative outcomes, in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The non-drainage group showed superior pain relief, better functional recovery (e.g., higher Hospital for Special Surgery knee score, improved mobility), reduced anesthetic consumption, and enhanced proprioception compared to the drainage group during the inpatient period. These benefits persisted at the 3-month follow-up, supporting non-drainage as the preferred option post-TKA.
population_specificity: 91 patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
study_duration: Outcomes assessed at discharge, postoperative day 7, and postoperative month 3.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nonpharmacological interventions, including walking tests, in improving respiratory function and ventilation in individuals with impaired ventilation.
results_summary: The study found that combined interventions, including educational components, were effective in improving pulmonary function, diffusion, oxygenation, and functional capacity, though walking specifically was not isolated as a primary intervention.
population_specificity: Adults with impaired ventilation in various clinical contexts.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of task-oriented training (TOT) and its combination with talocrural manual therapy (MT-TOT) on balance, mobility, and quality of life in chronic stroke patients, and to assess the feasibility of a larger RCT.
results_summary: Both MT-TOT and TOT improved balance, walking speed, mobility, ankle dorsiflexion range of motion, and certain HRQoL domains in stroke patients. The study confirmed the feasibility of a larger RCT.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients
effective_dosage: Supervised interventions: 45 min, 2x/week for 4 weeks; home-based practice: 20 min, 4x/week for 4 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of combined intra-articular injections (IAIs) and physical therapy (PT) treatments, including walking capability (WC), in patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA).
results_summary: The study found that mesenchymal stem cells (MSC) plus PT was the most effective treatment for enhancing walking capability recovery (SMD = 2.54). Combined IAI+PT treatments provided more benefits than monotherapies, with efficacy moderated by disease severity.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (KOA) (6934 patients across 80 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze spatio-temporal walking patterns of people with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS) and healthy individuals during the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) to assess walking endurance and efficiency.
results_summary: The study found significant changes in spatio-temporal walking parameters for PwMS between initial and final intervals of the 6MWT, indicating reduced walking efficiency, while healthy individuals maintained consistent patterns. These changes in PwMS exceeded standard measurement error, suggesting the alterations were due to their walking ability rather than measurement variability.
population_specificity: 45 people with Multiple Sclerosis (PwMS) and 24 healthy individuals.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (walking test, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, feasibility, and usability of the ABLE Exoskeleton for gait training in persons with spinal cord injury (SCI) in clinical settings.
results_summary: The study found that gait training with the ABLE Exoskeleton was safe, with few device-related adverse events, and led to improvements in gait parameters, walking function, and perceived exertion. Participants and therapists reported good satisfaction with the device, particularly in terms of safety, weight, durability, and dimensions.
population_specificity: Persons with subacute SCI (mainly <1 year after injury) from C5 to L3, ASIA Impairment Scale A to D.
effective_dosage: 12 training sessions with a follow-up visit after 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify literature on exercise programs, including walking, for hospitalized patients with acute heart failure to assess their safety and efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that walking, as part of aerobic exercise programs, improved physical function, functional capacity, and quality of life in patients with acute heart failure, with light to moderate intensity being predominant.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years old, hospitalized, and diagnosed with acute heart failure.
effective_dosage: Light to moderate intensity, progressively increased frequency and duration (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effectiveness of exercise therapy (including walking) versus invasive interventions for treating intermittent claudication in peripheral arterial disease patients.
results_summary: The study found sparse and insufficient data on walking distance and quality of life outcomes, limiting strong conclusions about walking's efficacy. Reintervention rates for endovascular therapy were high (>20% at ≥2 years), but walking-specific results were not robustly reported.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral arterial disease and intermittent claudication.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how walking and other health behaviors contribute to vitality and overall health, proposing an updated definition of health that includes physical and psychological well-being.
results_summary: The study found that walking and other aerobic activities promote vitality, which enhances resilience, agency, and overall health, initiating a virtuous cycle of positive health behaviors.
population_specificity: Adults, particularly those entering senior years with chronic diseases.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of a 12-week split-belt treadmill walking practice using an error augmentation strategy on gait asymmetries, dynamic balance, and locomotor capacity in adolescents with unilateral cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The split-belt treadmill walking group showed improved step-length asymmetry, dynamic balance, and locomotor performance compared to the control group. The adaptations suggest potential for remediating gait and balance deficits in this population.
population_specificity: Adolescents (ages 10-16) with unilateral cerebral palsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish reference values for clinical mobility tests in racially diverse older adults aged 50-95 years in the Southeast US.
results_summary: Performance on mobility tests declined with age, particularly in the ninth decade, with variations observed between racial groups. Black participants showed significant differences across age groups in several tests, while White participants had fewer significant differences.
population_specificity: 314 community-dwelling older adults (222 women), predominantly Black (n=121) or White (n=164), aged 50-95 years from the Atlanta, Georgia region.
study_duration: Data collected from 2011-2019 (observational period, not intervention duration)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of aerobic exercise, including walking, on metabolic indicators and physical performance in adults with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Aerobic exercise, including walking, significantly reduced weight, improved lipid profiles (lower triglycerides and LDL, higher HDL), reduced liver enzymes, and increased peak oxygen consumption in NAFLD patients.
population_specificity: Adults with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
effective_dosage: 30 to 60 minutes, 3 or more times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the historical understanding of astasia-abasia (a gait disorder) and its transition from being attributed to hysteria to being recognized as a syndrome with organic causes.
results_summary: The abstract summarizes the historical evolution of astasia-abasia, highlighting its reclassification from a hysterical condition to a syndrome with multiple organic causes, including frontal and cerebellar pathologies. It also notes the contributions of various neurologists in advancing the understanding of human bipedal locomotion.
population_specificity: Historical medical cases and neurologists' studies (no specific contemporary population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effectiveness, cost-effectiveness, and complication rates of total ankle replacement versus ankle fusion in treating end-stage ankle osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both total ankle replacement and ankle fusion improved patients' walking ability at 1 year, with no statistically significant difference in the primary outcome. Fixed-bearing total ankle replacement showed better outcomes than ankle fusion in a post hoc analysis.
population_specificity: Patients aged 50-85 years with end-stage ankle osteoarthritis, suitable for either procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of tai chi chuan versus fitness walking in improving cognitive function in older adults with type 2 diabetes and mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study found that tai chi chuan was more effective than fitness walking in improving global cognitive function at 36 weeks, though fitness walking still showed some benefit. Adverse events were minimal and not significantly different between groups.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged ≥60 years) with type 2 diabetes and mild cognitive impairment.
effective_dosage: 60 minutes per session, 3 times per week.
study_duration: 24 weeks of intervention, with follow-up at 36 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and describe the parameters that constitute action observation training (AOT) videos for stroke rehabilitation, particularly focusing on walking and upper limb dexterity.
results_summary: The study found that video length and perspective of view were the most-reported parameters in AOT protocols, while movement speed and sound were the least reported. Videos shorter than 5 minutes and specific perspectives (egocentric for upper limb, allocentric for walking) were suggested for optimal outcomes.
population_specificity: Stroke rehabilitation patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nature prescriptions, including walking, on cardiometabolic and mental health outcomes.
results_summary: Nature prescriptions, including walking, significantly improved systolic and diastolic blood pressure, depression and anxiety scores, and daily step counts, but did not significantly increase weekly moderate physical activity time.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population, likely including individuals referred by health or social professionals).
effective_dosage: Not specified (nature prescriptions involved spending time in nature, but exact walking duration/frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kinesio taping on the tibialis posterior or peroneus longus muscles improves foot posture, dynamic balance, and biomechanical parameters during functional tasks in individuals with flexible flatfoot.
results_summary: Kinesio taping on both muscles improved foot posture (reduced navicular drop and foot posture index). Tibialis posterior taping increased maximum total force during running and altered temporal parameters, while peroneus longus taping improved dynamic stability and coordination during tasks.
population_specificity: 30 women with flexible flatfoot.
effective_dosage: Not specified (Kinesio taping applied for 30 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of interlaminar full-endoscopic laminectomy versus open decompressive laminectomy for treating lumbar spinal stenosis, including functional measures like walking distance/time.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding walking outcomes, as the study is described as a planned randomized controlled trial with no reported findings yet.
population_specificity: 120 participants (60 per group) with lumbar spinal stenosis undergoing surgical treatment.
study_duration: Evaluations conducted preoperatively and at 2 weeks, 3, 6, and 12 months postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate factors influencing walking ability in patients hospitalized with aspiration pneumonia.
results_summary: The study found that nutritional status and early mobilization were key factors affecting walking ability preservation. Patients with better nutrition and early rehabilitation maintained their walking ability more effectively.
population_specificity: Patients hospitalized due to aspiration pneumonia (n=143).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe natural walking intensity in ambulatory persons with Parkinson’s disease (PD) and assess its alignment with physical activity guidelines.
results_summary: Most daily walking occurred at low intensities, with few sustained bouts of higher intensity. Participants walked predominantly in short, low-intensity bouts, highlighting the need for interventions to increase walking intensity.
population_specificity: Ambulatory persons with Parkinson’s disease (n=82).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of a supervised exercise therapy (SET) program for peripheral artery disease (PAD), specifically focusing on walking modalities that did not use a treadmill.
results_summary: The SET program significantly improved walking capacity (6-min walk test) across most groups, with no significant differences between the different walking modalities. Physical function measures did not show significant between-group changes for treadmill walking, total body recumbent stepping, or their combination.
population_specificity: White adults (55% female, mean age 73.7) with mild-moderate PAD in rural Midwest cardiac rehabilitation settings.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise program prescribed by an exercise physiologist or nurse based on SET guidelines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the intervention effect of concurrent training (including walking) on physical performance in children with malignant tumors.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that concurrent training, including walking, significantly improved muscle strength in children with malignant tumors compared to usual care, but had no significant effect on mental health. The quality of evidence was mostly very low, indicating a need for further high-quality studies.
population_specificity: Children with malignant tumors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional outcomes of full-endoscopic decompression versus tubular-based microscopic decompression in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis, focusing on walking time and other clinical measures.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in walking time between the two surgical groups, but full-endoscopic decompression showed advantages in reduced blood loss and shorter hospital stays. Both groups had similar high patient satisfaction rates (86.7% vs. 83.3%) at 24 months.
population_specificity: 60 patients with single-level lumbar spinal stenosis requiring decompression surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of home-based exercise, including walking, on physical fitness (cardiorespiratory fitness, muscle strength, and body composition) in cancer patients undergoing active treatment.
results_summary: Home-based exercise, including walking, improved the 6-minute walk test distance, but the effect was not significant when analyzing exclusively walking interventions. No improvements were found for muscle strength or body composition.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing active treatment, primarily breast cancer patients during adjuvant therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of pooled, allogeneic, adult human bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells in treating "no-option" patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI) due to atherosclerotic peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found statistically significant reductions in rest pain and ulcer size, improvements in ankle-brachial pressure index and ankle systolic pressure, enhanced quality of life, increased walking distance, and prolonged major amputation-free survival over 12 months.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity CLI due to PAD (Rutherford III-5 or III-6) and ankle-brachial pressure index ≤ 0.6, with at least one ulcer between 0.5 and 10 cm².
effective_dosage: 2 million cells/kg body weight injected into the calf muscle and around the ulcer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of unilateral, real-time audiovisual TLA versus AGRF biofeedback on gait biomechanics in post-stroke individuals.
results_summary: Both AGRF and TLA biofeedback increased paretic AGRF, with TLA biofeedback inducing larger increases in paretic TLA. AGRF biofeedback also increased ankle moment, and both conditions increased non-paretic step length without affecting the non-paretic limb.
population_specificity: Nine post-stroke individuals (6 males, age 63 ± 9.8 years, 44.9 months post-stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare and rank the efficacy of non-pharmacological interventions, including walking-related exercises, for improving physical function in adults with end-stage renal disease.
results_summary: Combined resistance and aerobic exercise with virtual reality or music was most effective for increasing walking distance, while resistance exercise with blood flow restriction improved handgrip strength. No interventions significantly improved quality of life.
population_specificity: Adults with end-stage renal disease

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding exercise (including walking) to a hypocaloric diet provided additional benefits for body weight, body composition, glycaemic control, and cardio-respiratory fitness in adults with overweight/obesity and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found no significant additional effects of exercise (including walking) combined with a hypocaloric diet on body weight, body composition, or glycaemic control compared to diet alone, though cardio-respiratory fitness improved.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight or obesity and type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise interventions varied, including walking, jogging, cycling, football, or resistance training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of smartphone use on turning behavior during walking in healthy individuals of different ages and those with neurological diseases.
results_summary: The study found that smartphone use during walking led to en bloc turning (reduced intersegmental coordination) across all age and disease groups, increasing fall risk, with Parkinson disease patients showing the most pronounced changes. Participants with stroke exhibited en bloc turning even without smartphone use, suggesting a compensatory strategy.
population_specificity: Younger (18-60 years) and older (>60 years) healthy individuals, and those with Parkinson disease, multiple sclerosis, subacute stroke (<4 weeks), or lower-back pain.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of low-intensity resistance training with blood flow restriction on fall resistance, including walking ability, in middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The study found that low-intensity resistance training with blood flow restriction significantly improved walking ability in middle-aged and older adults, along with lower limb muscle strength and muscle mass.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Active Strides-CP, a novel physiotherapy package, to usual care in improving gross motor function and participation outcomes for children with bilateral cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study will measure outcomes at baseline and post-intervention, but results are not yet reported in the abstract. The intervention includes functional electrical stimulation cycling, treadmill training, overground walking, and goal-directed training.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-15 years with bilateral cerebral palsy, classified as GMFCS levels III and IV.
effective_dosage: 8 weeks of Active Strides-CP, two times/week for 1.5 hours in clinic and one time/week for 1 hour alternating home visits and telehealth (total dose=32 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and safety of a tailored exercise program for patients with diabetes-related foot ulcers, addressing conflicting recommendations about walking and exercise.
results_summary: The study found high retention (95%) and acceptable adherence to follow-up (75%) and home exercise (50%), with no adverse events reported, suggesting targeted exercise is safe for this population.
population_specificity: Adults admitted to hospital with diabetes-related foot ulcers.
effective_dosage: Not specified (tailored aerobic and resistance exercises based on ulcer location).
study_duration: Not specified (single supervised session followed by home exercise prescription).

study_goal: To assess the impacts of 28 months of detraining due to COVID-19 on the functional fitness of older women practicing functional or concurrent training, including walking ability.
results_summary: Functional training (FT) and concurrent training (CT) groups showed smaller reductions in functional fitness compared to the control group (CG) after detraining, particularly in upper limb function (PTS) and walking ability (W10 m). The study concluded that FT and CT were effective strategies for maintaining functional fitness in older women despite prolonged detraining.
population_specificity: Older women (ages 65.0 ± 4.3 to 69.6 ± 5.9 years).
study_duration: 16 weeks of intervention, followed by 28 months of detraining.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of transcranial direct current stimulation combined with treadmill training on dual-task gait performance and contralesional cortical activity in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The cathodal transcranial direct current stimulation + treadmill training group showed significant improvements in cognitive dual-task walking speed and contralesional cortical activity compared to other groups, while no significant benefits were observed in the bilateral stimulation group.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients
effective_dosage: 20 min transcranial direct current stimulation followed by 30 min treadmill training, 3 sessions per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of spontaneous non-aneurysmal popliteal artery dissection and discuss diagnostic and treatment options.
results_summary: The study found that spontaneous dissection of a non-aneurysmal popliteal artery is extremely rare and can be diagnosed via duplex ultrasonography or CT angiography. The patient's condition resolved spontaneously with conservative management (antiplatelet medication), avoiding surgery.
population_specificity: A 61-year-old man with sudden onset of leg pain after walking 60 meters.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether recent studies on gait in autistic children considered cultural factors in their analysis.
results_summary: The scoping review found 43 eligible articles, none of which accounted for cultural factors in their data analysis, highlighting a gap in culturally responsive research.
population_specificity: Autistic children across various racial and cultural backgrounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic benefits of commercial video games, including improvements in physical condition (e.g., walking speed) and cognitive functions, in individuals with schizophrenia.
results_summary: The study found associations between video gaming and better outcomes in physical condition (walking speed, aerobic fitness), neurocognition (processing speed, memory, executive functions), and social functioning, self-efficacy, and quality of life in schizophrenia patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with schizophrenia and related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the walking efficiency of lower limb exoskeleton gait orthosis versus mechanical gait orthosis in patients with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found that both lower limb exoskeleton gait orthosis and mechanical gait orthosis improved gait outcomes in patients with spinal cord injury, based on kinematic data and clinical tests, though more high-quality studies are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal cord injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 16-week dance intervention could improve frailty, depression, and physical performance in Chinese older adults living in the community.
results_summary: The dance intervention significantly reduced frailty and depression while improving short physical performance battery scores compared to the control group. These improvements were observed over the 16-week period.
population_specificity: Chinese older adults living in the community setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of early mobilization (including walking) versus 48-hour bed rest on medical complications and functional outcomes after burr hole craniostomy for chronic subdural hematoma.
results_summary: Early mobilization reduced medical complications (19.2% vs. 34.6%) without significantly increasing surgical recurrence (7.7% vs. 4.8%) and showed a trend toward better functional outcomes (81.7% vs. 72.1% favorable GOSE scores).
population_specificity: Patients who underwent burr hole craniostomy for chronic subdural hematoma (n=208).
effective_dosage: Early mobilization included head-of-bed elevation within 12 hours, progressing to sitting, standing, and walking as tolerated.
study_duration: Intervention duration was until clinical discharge, with follow-up at 1 month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of extended natalizumab dosing (Q6W) versus standard dosing (Q4W) in maintaining disease control and patient-reported outcomes in stable relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis patients.
results_summary: No significant differences were found between Q6W and Q4W dosing in clinical or patient-reported outcomes, except for a higher proportion of Q6W patients showing worsening in the EQ-5D-5L index score.
population_specificity: Patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis who were stable on natalizumab Q4W for ≥12 months.
effective_dosage: 300 mg intravenously every 6 weeks (Q6W) vs. every 4 weeks (Q4W).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine prognostic factors for respiratory failure and inability to walk in children with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) and develop a clinical prognostic model (EGRIS-Kids).
results_summary: The study found that EGRIS-Kids, incorporating age, cranial nerve involvement, and GBS disability score at admission, predicted respiratory failure risk (AUC = 0.71). A lower GBS disability score at nadir strongly predicted recovery to independent walking.
population_specificity: Children under 18 years with GBS from Germany, Switzerland, Austria, and The Netherlands.
study_duration: Follow-up at one year after diagnosis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a 6-month progressive walking and education program for preventing low back pain recurrences compared to a no-treatment control group.
results_summary: The study will assess time to recurrence of activity-limiting low back pain, disability levels, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness, but final results are not yet reported in the abstract. The planned analysis includes Cox regression and linear mixed models to evaluate outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk of low back pain recurrences.
effective_dosage: Progressive and individualized walking program (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate clinical guidelines on exercise, including walking, for women with gestational diabetes mellitus to identify consensus and inconsistencies in recommendations.
results_summary: The study found consistent recommendations supporting walking as a safe and effective exercise for women with gestational diabetes mellitus, typically suggesting 30 minutes per session on 5 days a week or daily after meals at moderate intensity.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with gestational diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, 5 days a week or daily after meals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether diagnostic imaging findings (e.g., radiographic OA severity, effusion, bone marrow lesions) modify the treatment effects of non-surgical interventions (e.g., exercise therapy, intra-articular injections, unloading shoes) in knee and hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that radiographic knee OA severity modified the effect of unloading shoes on walking pain, with more severe cases showing greater response. No interaction was found between radiographic OA severity or joint effusion and the effect of intra-articular injections in hip OA.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee or hip osteoarthritis.
